tutorial.python:
from player_code import (
    Position,
    Attacker,
    Defender,
    AttackerType,
    DefenderType,
    Constants,
    Map,
    State,
    Game,
    is_valid_spawn_position,
)

#In this tutorial, we will learn how to spawn multiple troops in the same turn at different positions.

# This is the function player has to fill
# You can define any new functions here that you want
def run(state: State) -> Game:
    # Always start by instantiating a Game class object
    game = Game()
    game.log("TURN {} LOGS:\n".format(state.turn_no))

    defenders = state.defenders
    
    # Set the type of the attacker to spawn
    # typeId can be 1/2/3
    type_id1 = 2
    type_id2 = 3

    # If there's no defenders left, we can stop spawning and save up on coins,
    # which are important for boosting game score
    if len(defenders) != 0:
        sample_pos = Position(0,0)
        game.spawn_attacker(type_id1,sample_pos)
        # for i in range(0,3):
            # You can spawn multiple attackers in the same turn, but not at the same position.

            # create Position objects, so as to spawn different types of troops
            # at different places
            # On the 64x64 map, you can spawn troops only at the 4 edges of the map
            # i.e., either x or y has to be 0 or 63
            
            # There are two cases when you might be penalized
            # - Spawning at an invalid position
            # - Spawning at a position where you have already spawned one attacker
            # in the same turn
            #
            # We have provided helpers to check just that

            # game class will keep track of all your spawned positions for you and
            # provides a helper method called already_spawned_at_position(Position)
            # to check if you already spawned in the position

            # Mostly a good practice to check with these two helpers before spawning,
            # to save up on accidental penalties
                
            # Check with the helpers and spawn more troops here
                

    # Lets log all the spawned positions for this turn
    for type_id, pos in game.spawn_positions:
        game.log("Type {} at Position ({},{})".
            format(type_id, pos.x, pos.y))

    # always return the game object
    return game

from player_code import (
    Position,
    Attacker,
    Defender,
    AttackerType,
    DefenderType,
    Constants,
    Map,
    State,
    Game,
    is_valid_spawn_position,
)
#In this tutorial, we will learn how to set targets.

# This is the function player has to fill
# You can define any new functions here that you want
def run(state: State) -> Game:
    # Always start by instantiating a Game class object
    game = Game()
    game.log("TURN {} LOGS:".format(state.get_turn_no()))

    # Get all the attackers and defenders in the game and store it
    attackers = state.attackers
    defenders = state.defenders
    
    # Set the type of the attacker to spawn
    # typeId can be 1/2/3
    type_id1 = 2
    type_id2 = 3

    # If there's no defenders left, we can stop spawning and save up on coins,
    # which are important for boosting game score
    if len(defenders) != 0:

        for i in range(0,3):
            # You can spawn multiple attackers in the same turn, but not at the same position.

            # create Position objects, so as to spawn different types of troops
            # at different places

            # There are two cases when you might be penalized
            # - Spawning at an invalid position
            # - Spawning at a position where you have already spawned one attacker
            # in the same turn
            #
            # We have provided helpers to check just that

            # game class will keep track of all your spawned positions for you and
            # provides a helper method called alreadySpawnedAtPosition(Position)
            # to check if you already spawned in the position

            # Mostly a good practice to check with these two helpers before spawning,
            # to save up on accidental penalties
            if is_valid_spawn_position(position1) and \
                    not game.is_already_spawned_at_position(position1) and \
                    is_valid_spawn_position(position2) and \
                    not game.is_already_spawned_at_position(position2):
                # spawn attackers here
                

    # Now let's say you always want to set the target for the attackers[0] to
    # defenders[0]
    # To do that you do
    if attackers and defenders:
        # check if they are empty beforehand to be safe from unexpected errors
        game.set_target(attackers[0].get_id(), defenders[0].get_id())

        # try experimenting with your own targets
        # read the docs for more about the set_target function

    # Lets log all the spawned positions for this turn
    for entry in game.get_spawn_positions():
        game.log("Type {} at Position({}, {})".format(
            entry.get_type_id(), entry.get_pos().get_x(), entry.get_pos().get_y()))

    # always return the game object
    return game

# This is the function player has to fill

def run(state: State) -> Game:

    game = Game()
    game.log("TURN {} LOGS:".format(state.get_turn_no()))

    # Get all the attackers and defenders in the game and store it
    attackers = state.attackers
    defenders = state.defenders
    
    # Set the type of the attacker to spawn
    # typeId can be 1/2/3
    type_id1 = 2
    type_id2 = 3

    # If there's no defenders left, we can stop spawning and save up on coins,
    # which are important for boosting game score
    if len(defenders) != 0:

        for i in range(0,3):
            # You can spawn multiple attackers in the same turn, but not at the same position.

            # create Position objects, so as to spawn different types of troops
            # at different places

            # There are two cases when you might be penalized

                    is_valid_spawn_position(position2) and \
                    not game.is_already_spawned_at_position(position2):
                # spawn attackers here
                

    # This has the starting attributes for the attacker we are about to
    # spawn
    # For full information about the Attributes class, refer to the
    # documentation
    # This information can be used for strategizing
    attackers_attributes1: AttackerType = Constants.ATTACKER_TYPE_ATTRIBUTES[type_id1]
    attackers_attributes2: AttackerType = Constants.ATTACKER_TYPE_ATTRIBUTES[type_id2]

    if attackers and defenders:
        # check if they are empty beforehand to be safe from unexpected errors
        for defender in defenders:
            if attackers_attributes1.is_aerial == 1:
                # set the target for aerial attackers to target aerial defenses
                
            if attackers_attributes2.is_aerial == 1:
                # set the target for aerial attackers to target aerial defenses
                

            # strategize by using the other attributes by referring to the documentation

    # Lets log all the spawned positions for this turn
    for entry in game.get_spawn_positions():
        game.log("Type {} at Position({}, {})".format(
            entry.get_type_id(), entry.get_pos().get_x(), entry.get_pos().get_y()))

    # always return the game object
    return game

tutorial.python:
from player_code import (
    Position,
    Attacker,
    Defender,
    AttackerType,
    DefenderType,
    Constants,
    Map,
    State,
    Game,
    is_valid_spawn_position,
    get_all_valid_spawn_positions,
)

def run(state: State) -> Game:
    global last_spawned
    game = Game()
    game.log("TURN {} LOGS:\n".format(state.turn_no))
    attackers = state.attackers
    defenders = state.defenders
    type_id_1 = 2
    type_id_2 = 3
    if len(defenders) != 0:
        for i in range(0, 11):
            position1 = Position(25 + i, 0)
            position2 = Position(25 + i, 63)
            if is_valid_spawn_position(position1) and \
                    not game.is_already_spawned_at_position(position1):
                game.spawn_attacker(type_id_1, position1)
            if is_valid_spawn_position(position2) and \
                    not game.is_already_spawned_at_position(position2):
                game.spawn_attacker(type_id_2, position2)

    # Let's log all the spawned positions for this turn
    for type_id, pos in game.spawn_positions:
        game.log("Type {} at Position ({},{})".
                 format(type_id, pos.x, pos.y))

    # always return the game object
    return game
